standard.name: ISO 27001
standard.description: ISO 27001 is a specification for an information security management system (ISMS). It is designed to align with key principles to ensure information security, including confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data. For KYC, it ensures that customer data is protected.

requirements.name: Data Protection Policies
requirements.description: Establish and maintain data protection policies to secure customer information during the KYC process, preventing unauthorized access or data breaches.

requirements.name: Access Control Mechanisms
requirements.description: Implement access control mechanisms to ensure that only authorized personnel have access to customer information during the KYC process.

standard.name: AML/CFT Regulations
standard.description: Anti-Money Laundering (AML) and Countering Financing of Terrorism (CFT) regulations are designed to ensure financial institutions identify and mitigate risks related to money laundering and terrorist financing through diligent KYC procedures.

requirements.name: Customer Identity Verification
requirements.description: Mandatory verification of customer identity using reliable, independent source documents, data, or information as part of the KYC process.

requirements.name: Transaction Monitoring
requirements.description: Ongoing monitoring of customer transactions to identify and report suspicious activities or inconsistencies that may indicate money laundering or terrorism financing.

controls.name: Identity Verification Procedures
controls.description: Establish procedures for verifying the identity of customers using government-issued IDs and other reliable documentations during onboarding. This must be done at the start of the customer relationship and reviewed periodically thereafter.

controls.name: Automated Monitoring Systems
controls.description: Deploy advanced automated systems to continuously monitor and detect unusual transaction patterns or activities. Regularly update the system to adapt to new threats. This control mitigates risks of financial crime and ensures compliance with AML/CFT requirements.

controls.name: Access Log Reviews
controls.description: Implement regular reviews of access logs to ensure adherence to access control policies and detect any unauthorized access or anomalies. These reviews should occur monthly.

risks.name: Identity Fraud
risks.description: Identity fraud occurs when an individual provides false identity information to bypass security checks, leading to potential financial losses and reputational harm to the organization.

risks.name: Money Laundering Activities
risks.description: Without effective monitoring, customers may engage in money laundering, leading to legal penalties and severe reputational damage. Continuous monitoring mitigates this risk by identifying suspicious activities early.

risks.name: Unauthorized Data Access
risks.description: Unauthorized access to customer data can lead to data breaches and legal compliance issues, harming the organization's reputation and trustworthiness. Regular access log reviews help in early detection of such unauthorized attempts.

standard.name: ISO 31000
standard.description: Provides guidelines on managing risk faced by organizations. The standard offers a universally applicable framework for risk management processes.

requirements.name: Risk Assessment
requirements.description: Comprehensive identification of risks to ensure all potential hazards related to loan applications are identified, analyzed, and evaluated for significance.

requirements.name: Risk Treatment Planning
requirements.description: Developing treatment plans to mitigate identified risks to acceptable levels within the organization, focusing on minimizing incidents related to mismanagement of loan applications.

standard.name: Basel III
standard.description: Designed to strengthen regulation, supervision, and risk management within the banking sector by improving the bank's ability to manage unexpected risks.

requirements.name: Capital Adequacy Requirements
requirements.description: Ensure sufficient capital reserves are maintained to protect against losses, crucial for handling defaults in loan applications.

requirements.name: Credit Risk Management
requirements.description: Implementation of robust credit risk assessment mechanisms to evaluate the creditworthiness of loan applicants effectively.

controls.name: Applicant Creditworthiness Evaluation
controls.description: Perform thorough credit checks and background investigations on applicants to ensure they meet the bank’s lending criteria, thereby reducing the likelihood of default.

controls.name: Regular Risk Review
controls.description: Quarterly review meetings to examine the effectiveness of existing risk management controls and adjustments if necessary.

risks.name: Credit Default Risk
risks.description: The potential impact includes financial loss due to the inability of a borrower to make loan repayments. If not addressed, this risk can lead to significant capital losses.

risks.name: Regulatory Compliance Risk
risks.description: Potential for regulatory penalties and loss of reputation if compliance with loan processing regulations is not strictly adhered to.

standard.name: ISO 19600: Compliance Management Systems
standard.description: This standard provides guidance for establishing, developing, implementing, evaluating, maintaining and improving an effective and responsive compliance management system within an organization. Applicable to all types of organizations, regardless of size or industry.

requirements.name: Compliance Commitment
requirements.description: Establish a visible commitment to compliance, ensuring that top management visibly supports compliance initiatives and that there is a culture of compliance throughout the organization.

requirements.name: Risk Assessments
requirements.description: Conduct regular compliance risk assessments to identify and evaluate potential breaches, ensuring all compliance risks are understood and monitored.

standard.name: Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX)
standard.description: A regulatory framework to ensure transparency in financial reporting and corporate governance in public companies. Mandated to protect stakeholders from fraudulent activities and accounting errors.

requirements.name: Internal Controls for Financial Reporting
requirements.description: Implement and test internal controls to guarantee the accuracy of financial data and mitigate risks related to financial misstatements.

requirements.name: Disclosure Controls
requirements.description: Ensure timely and accurate disclosure of material financial and operational information to stakeholders.

controls.name: Regular Compliance Audits
controls.description: Conducting regular compliance audits every quarter to ensure all policies and procedures comply with relevant standards and regulations, identify potential non-compliance areas, and initiate corrective actions.

controls.name: Automated Compliance Monitoring Systems
controls.description: Implementing automated systems to continuously monitor compliance data, alerting to potential breaches in real-time to allow for swift corrective actions.

controls.name: Compliance Training Programs
controls.description: Developing robust training programs for all employees, mandating annual training sessions to reinforce the understanding of compliance processes and expectations.

risks.name: Regulatory Fines and Penalties
risks.description: Failure to implement effective compliance checks may result in significant fines or penalties from regulatory bodies, harming the company's financial standing and reputation.

risks.name: Operational Disruptions
risks.description: Non-compliance can lead to operational shutdowns or disruptions, impacting business continuity and leading to potential revenue losses.

risks.name: Reputational Damage
risks.description: Non-compliance incidents can severely damage the organization's reputation, resulting in loss of customer trust and potential market share.

standard.name: ISO 20022
standard.description: ISO 20022 is a global standard for electronic data interchange between financial institutions. It provides a standardized approach to insure secure and efficient transactions processing, including deposits and withdrawals.

requirements.name: Message Format Standardization
requirements.description: Ensure that all deposit and withdrawal messages follow the ISO 20022 standardized format to facilitate uniform understanding and processing across all financial institutions.

requirements.name: Data Integrity Verification
requirements.description: Implement mechanisms to verify the integrity of transactional data to prevent unauthorized modifications during transmission.

standard.name: Basel III
standard.description: Basel III is an international regulatory framework designed to enhance bank regulation, supervision, and risk management. It focuses on improving the banking sector's ability to deal with financial stress, enhance risk management, and strengthen banks' transparency in deposits and withdrawal processes.

requirements.name: Capital Adequacy Management
requirements.description: Banks must maintain a certain ratio of capital to risk-weighted assets to ensure stability during financial operations such as deposits and withdrawals.

requirements.name: Liquidity Risk Monitoring
requirements.description: Continuous monitoring and management of the bank's liquidity to ensure that it can meet withdrawal demands at all times without facing liquidity crises.

controls.name: Transaction Authentication Mechanism
controls.description: Implement multi-factor authentication for processing deposits and withdrawals. This control reduces the risk of unauthorized transactions and ensures all transactions are legitimate.

controls.name: Daily Reconciliation of Accounts
controls.description: Perform daily reconciliations of deposit and withdrawal accounts to detect discrepancies early. Regular monitoring helps maintain accuracy in financial records and safeguard against transaction errors.

risks.name: Unauthorized Access to Accounts
risks.description: If not controlled, unauthorized access can lead to fraudulent transactions, financial losses, and reputational damage to the organization. Transaction Authentication Mechanism mitigates this by verifying user identity before processing.

risks.name: Financial Discrepancies
risks.description: Financial discrepancies in deposits and withdrawals can lead to inaccurate financial reporting, which may affect decision-making and damage stakeholder trust. Daily reconciliation minimizes these risks by ensuring records are accurate and discrepancies are resolved promptly.

standard.name: ISO 10002:2018
standard.description: This standard provides guidelines for organizations to plan, design, develop, operate, maintain, and improve an effective complaints handling process within an organization. It applies to the handling of product-related complaints and customer service complaints.

requirements.name: Complaints Handling Framework
requirements.description: Organizations should have a structured framework for handling complaints. This involves policies, procedures, and responsibilities for handling complaints efficiently and effectively.

requirements.name: Customer Feedback Mechanism
requirements.description: A system for receiving and analyzing customer feedback should be established. It should include channels for customers to submit feedback easily and a process to evaluate the feedback for improvement.

standard.name: ITIL Customer Service Management
standard.description: The Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) framework provides best practices for aligning IT services with business needs, including customer service management. It ensures that customer services are managed effectively to improve customer satisfaction.

requirements.name: Service Level Agreements (SLAs)
requirements.description: Define and document SLAs to set clear expectations between the service provider and the customer on service delivery and support.

requirements.name: Continuous Improvement
requirements.description: Establish a continuous improvement process to enhance customer service operations through regular assessment and refinement of services.

controls.name: Monthly Complaints Review Meetings
controls.description: Hold monthly meetings to review all customer complaints received, analyze them, and determine appropriate actions to address any identified issues. This control ensures accountability and that proper measures are in place to handle complaints effectively.

controls.name: Quarterly Analysis of Customer Feedback Trends
controls.description: Conduct a thorough review and analysis of customer feedback every quarter to identify trends and areas necessitating improvements. Regular analysis aids decision-makers to enhance processes and meet customer expectations.

controls.name: SLA Compliance Monitoring
controls.description: Monitor and report on SLA compliance on a regular basis to ensure service delivery expectations are met. This control mitigates risks associated with service delivery failures.

risks.name: Inadequate Complaint Resolution
risks.description: Failure to resolve customer complaints adequately can lead to decreased customer satisfaction and potential loss of business. Regular review meetings address this risk by ensuring proactive resolution.

risks.name: Ignoring Customer Feedback
risks.description: Failure to act on customer feedback can result in missing opportunities for improvement and higher dissatisfaction rates. Quarterly feedback analysis helps prevent this risk.

risks.name: Non-Compliance with SLAs
risks.description: Non-compliance with SLAs can damage customer relationships and result in financial penalties. Monitoring SLA compliance ensures alignment with customer expectations and reduces these risks.

standard.name: ISO 31000: Risk Management Guidelines
standard.description: ISO 31000 provides guidelines on managing risk faced by organizations. The framework applies to any organization regardless of size, activity, or sector and aims to create and protect value by managing risks, improving performance, encouraging innovation, and supporting the achievement of objectives.

requirements.name: Establishing the Context
requirements.description: Define the external and internal context of the organization, its risk management policy, and risk criteria. This is essential to align risk management with organizational objectives.

requirements.name: Risk Assessment
requirements.description: Conduct systematic risk identification, risk analysis, and risk evaluation. It is critical for understanding risk exposure and developing a prioritized approach to managing risks.

requirements.name: Risk Treatment Planning
requirements.description: Develop and implement options for addressing identified risks. This is vital for ensuring appropriate responses to potential risk scenarios in alignment with the organization's risk appetite.

standard.name: COSO ERM: Enterprise Risk Management Framework
standard.description: The COSO Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) framework provides a comprehensive approach to managing enterprise risk, focusing on aligning risk with strategy and performance. It is applicable across industries and emphasizes the importance of governance, culture, and performance management in risk management.

requirements.name: Risk Governance
requirements.description: Establish oversight responsibilities and structures to govern risk management efforts. This is important for integrating risk oversight into strategic planning and organizational governance.

requirements.name: Risk Data and Technology
requirements.description: Utilize data management and technology resources effectively to support informed risk decision-making. Ensures data-driven insights are accessible for identifying and managing risks.

controls.name: Regular Risk Assessments
controls.description: Perform regular risk assessments to identify and evaluate new and existing risks. This control mitigates the risk of unexpected events adversely affecting the organization by ensuring that risks are continuously monitored. Frequency: Quarterly.

controls.name: Risk Mitigation Strategies
controls.description: Develop and implement robust risk mitigation strategies tailored to identified risks. This control is essential to ensure effective responses to risks have been planned and are ready to be deployed. Frequency: Annually and after major incidents.

controls.name: Risk Communication and Reporting
controls.description: Maintain clear communication channels for risk reporting and ensure the accuracy and timeliness of risk-related information shared across the organization. Ensures stakeholders are well-informed about risk levels and necessary actions. Frequency: Monthly.

risks.name: Operational Disruption
risks.description: A failure to identify and respond to new risks in a timely manner may lead to operational disruptions, resulting in potential financial losses and reputational damage. This risk is mitigated by regular risk assessments (linked to CTRL-0001) to ensure emerging risks are promptly identified.

risks.name: Inadequate Risk Treatment
risks.description: Lack of effective mitigation strategies can result in significant financial losses or compliance failures. This risk is addressed by risk mitigation strategies (linked to CTRL-0002), which provide structured plans for addressing those risks.

risks.name: Poor Risk Communication
risks.description: Inadequate communication of risk information can lead to uninformed decision-making and increased exposure. This risk is managed through Risk Communication and Reporting (linked to CTRL-0003), which ensures information flow is effective and accurate.

standard.name: ISO 27001
standard.description: ISO 27001 is an international standard on how to manage information security. It provides a framework for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an information security management system (ISMS). This is vitally important for protecting sensitive data during the account opening process and ensuring data privacy and compliance with global regulations.

requirements.name: Information Security Management System (ISMS) Policy
requirements.description: Establish an information security management policy that outlines the objectives and scope of the ISMS, tailored specifically to the account opening process. This policy is crucial for setting the foundation and guiding the security practices of the organization.

requirements.name: Risk Assessment
requirements.description: Conduct regular risk assessments to identify, analyze, and evaluate risks related to the account opening process. The assessments help prioritize security efforts and ensure that controls are effectively designed to mitigate identified risks.

standard.name: PCI-DSS
standard.description: The Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI-DSS) ensures that organizations securely handle credit card information. This standard is critical during the account opening process, especially if payment information is collected or stored, to prevent fraud and data breaches.

requirements.name: Secure Data Transmission
requirements.description: Use strong cryptography and security protocols to protect cardholder data during transmission. This requirement is vital to prevent interception and unauthorized access during the account opening process.

requirements.name: Data Retention and Disposal Policies
requirements.description: Implement data retention and secure disposal policies for cardholder data. These policies help in minimizing storage amounts and protect the data throughout its lifecycle.

controls.name: Identity Verification Protocol
controls.description: Implement a robust identity verification protocol to authenticate the identity of customers during the account opening process. This control is crucial for preventing identity fraud and ensuring compliance with KYC (Know Your Customer) regulations. It should be performed at every account opening.

controls.name: Data Encryption
controls.description: Ensure that all sensitive data collected during the account opening process is encrypted both in transit and at rest. This control mitigates the risk of unauthorized data access and data breaches. Encryption should be monitored continuously.

risks.name: Identity Theft
risks.description: The risk of individuals presenting false identification to open accounts. This could lead to fraudulent activities and financial losses for the organization and affect its reputation. Controlled via identity verification protocols.

risks.name: Data Breach
risks.description: The risk of unauthorized access to sensitive customer information, which could result in substantial legal penalties, financial losses, and reputational damage. This risk can be mitigated through data encryption measures.

standard.name: International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS)
standard.description: IFRS are a set of accounting standards developed by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) that provide guidelines for financial reporting. Its purpose is to ensure transparency, accountability, and efficiency in financial markets globally. IFRS are applicable to public companies and provide principles for recognizing, measuring, and disclosing items in financial statements.

requirements.name: Presentation of Financial Statements
requirements.description: Entities should present a complete set of financial statements at least annually. This requirement ensures that financial statements are prepared consistently and provide a true and fair view, following the principles of transparency and comparability.

requirements.name: Revenue Recognition
requirements.description: Entities must recognize revenue when (or as) the entity fulfills a performance obligation by transferring promised goods or services to a customer. This ensures accurate and timely revenue reporting, crucial for decision-making by stakeholders.

requirements.name: Disclosure of Accounting Policies
requirements.description: Entities should disclose significant accounting policies to provide clarity on the judgments and estimates that can significantly impact the reported financial condition. It supports transparency and uniform understanding of financial data.

standard.name: Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX) Section 404
standard.description: SOX Section 404 mandates the implementation of internal controls over financial reporting and requires management and external auditors to report on the adequacy of these controls. It aims to improve the accuracy and reliability of corporate disclosures.

requirements.name: Internal Control Assessment
requirements.description: Companies must assess the effectiveness of internal controls over financial reporting. This requirement is crucial for identifying potential weaknesses that could impact the integrity of financial statements.

requirements.name: Management Certification
requirements.description: Executives must certify the accuracy and completeness of financial reports. This adds a layer of accountability and responsibility, ensuring reports are accurate and comply with all relevant laws.

controls.name: Financial Statement Reconciliation
controls.description: Monthly reconciliation of general ledger accounts to ensure accuracy and completeness of financial reports. This control helps detect errors or irregularities early and ensures the financial statements reflect true financial position.

controls.name: Access Control to Financial Systems
controls.description: Restrict access to financial systems and records to authorized personnel only. This control prevents unauthorized entries and potential manipulation of financial data. It should be reviewed quarterly to ensure alignment with current roles and responsibilities.

controls.name: Regular Internal Audits
controls.description: Conduct regular internal audits to evaluate the effectiveness of accounting practices and internal controls. These audits help identify weaknesses and ensure compliance with standards like IFRS and SOX. It is recommended to conduct these audits bi-annually.

risks.name: Misstatement of Financial Results
risks.description: Errors or intentional manipulation of financial data could lead to inaccurate financial reporting. This risk relates to financial statement reconciliation because inaccuracies discovered during reconciliation could indicate broader issues, impacting decision-making and the organization's credibility if not addressed.

risks.name: Unauthorized Access to Financial Data
risks.description: Unauthorized users might alter critical financial data leading to inaccuracies and potential fraud. This risk is mitigated by restricting access to financial systems, as unauthorized access could compromise sensitive information and lead to financial losses.

risks.name: Non-Compliance with Accounting Standards
risks.description: Failing to comply with standards such as IFRS or SOX could result in regulatory penalties and damage to the organization's reputation. Regular internal audits help identify areas of non-compliance early to mitigate this risk.

standard.name: International Standards on Auditing (ISA)
standard.description: The International Standards on Auditing (ISA) are auditing guidelines developed by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC) through the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB). These standards are applicable to auditing financial statements and are designed to promote consistency and quality in audit processes globally. They include principles and essential procedures for auditors to follow, ensuring high-quality and reliable audits.

requirements.name: Audit Evidence
requirements.description: This requirement emphasizes the necessity of obtaining sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to draw reasonable conclusions on which to base the audit opinion. It ensures that the auditors collect reliable data before forming a conclusion, which is crucial to the integrity of the audit.

requirements.name: Planning and Risk Assessment
requirements.description: It involves assessing risks and planning the audit accordingly, focusing on areas with greater risk. This requirement is key to efficient resource allocation and ensuring that high-risk areas are prioritized during the audit.

standard.name: Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX) Section 404
standard.description: The SOX Act is a U.S. law aimed at enhancing corporate governance and strengthening the quality of financial reporting. Section 404 specifically mandates that management and auditors establish and maintain adequate internal control structures and procedures to ensure the accuracy and reliability of financial reporting. It applies to all publicly held companies and is enforced vigorously to enhance accountability.

requirements.name: Internal Control Assessment
requirements.description: Management and external auditors must evaluate the effectiveness of the company's internal controls. This requirement stresses the continuous monitoring and testing of controls throughout the audit process to ensure reliability and compliance with financial reporting standards.

requirements.name: Disclosures in Financial Reports
requirements.description: This emphasizes the need for transparent and accurate disclosures in financial reports. It requires auditors to verify the completeness and truthfulness of disclosures, which is vital for maintaining trust and compliance with regulatory requirements.

controls.name: Continuous Audit Evidence Gathering
controls.description: Establish a system for continuous collection and evaluation of audit evidence throughout the audit process. Regular checks and balances are integral to the process and are implemented weekly to ensure that the data collected is consistent and no critical information is missed.

controls.name: Risk-focused Audit Planning
controls.description: Implementation of a dynamic audit planning tool that prioritizes audit tasks according to identified risk levels. This control is executed quarterly, ensuring that high-risk areas receive timely attention in the audit process. It mitigates risks by ensuring focused and effective audit resource allocation.

controls.name: Regular Internal Control Testing
controls.description: Conduct regular internal control testing and validation exercises to ensure compliance with established control frameworks. This testing occurs monthly and is crucial for early identification and mitigation of control failures.

risks.name: Insufficient Audit Evidence
risks.description: Failure to gather sufficient audit evidence can lead to incorrect audit conclusions, impacting the accuracy and reliability of the audit report. This risk is managed by Continuous Audit Evidence Gathering, ensuring that all necessary evidence supports audit opinions.

risks.name: Audit Plan Ineffectiveness
risks.description: An ineffective audit plan can lead to resource wastage and missed high-risk areas, compromising audit quality. This risk is mitigated by Risk-focused Audit Planning, which ensures that the most critical areas are effectively audited by aligning the focus with identified risks.

risks.name: Control Failures
risks.description: Unidentified control failures can result in non-compliance issues and impact financial reporting reliability. Regular Internal Control Testing addresses this risk by routinely validating the effectiveness of internal controls, thus preventing significant control oversights.
